explanation:
Correct calculation: \( q = 180^{\circ} - 126^{\circ} = 54^{\circ} \).  
Student's error: \( 180^{\circ} - 126^{\circ} - 37^{\circ} = 17^{\circ} \).  

The student incorrectly treated the 37° angle (from a separate intersection) as part of the same linear pair as \( q \). This led them to subtract both 126° and 37° from 180°, assuming all marked angles lie on the same straight-line segment.  

The flaw stems from conflating angles from distinct linear pairs (left and right intersections) into a single calculation. This distinguishes the error from related misconceptions like assuming angles on a straight line sum to 90° or 100°, as the student correctly used 180° but misapplied it to non-adjacent angles.
